title: Australians voting for which country they would move to overwhelmingly chose one location
text:
While many Australians believe they live in the best country in the world, when asked if they had to jump ship most people opted for somewhere very close to home.

Most Australians have chosen New Zealand as the place they would most like to live.

In the ABC's Australia Talks National Survey, 28 per cent of Aussies chose the country quite close to home, with Canada coming a close second.

Results of a survey has found Australians would jump ship to nearby New Zealand if they were forced to leave the country (Bay of Plenty on the North Island pictured)

At least 28 per cent of Australians would choose to go to New Zealand as the place they would most like to live (All Blacks pictured doing to Haka)

The majority of the English-speaking, Anglo-Saxon population surveyed chose countries who also have a mostly English-speaking population.

But New Zealand was even popular among non-white Australians, with 20 per cent choosing it as their ideal option.

The revelation comes after a surge of Australians were looking to move to New Zealand following the Coalition's shock election victory in May.

It was revealed that ten times as many Australians were looking at the Immigration New Zealand website.

Expressions of interest also increased by more than 25 times around the same time.

More than 8,500 people visited the New Zealand Now website the day after the election and 512 registered interest - the first step in the visa process - compared to about 20 registrations on May 12, Immigration New Zealand said.

New Zealand was even popular among non-white Australians, with 20 per cent choosing it as their ideal option (Hobbit house pictured)

Most people in Australia trust New Zealand and their government (Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern pictured) more than their own country to 'do the right thing in the world'

WHERE AUSSIES WANT TO LIVE: New Zealand - 28 per cent Canada - 15 per cent England - 8 per cent United States - 6 per cent France - 3 per cent Japan - 3 per cent Italy - 3 per cent Sweden - 2 per cent Norway - 2 per cent Denmark - 2 per cent Source: ABC's Australia Talks National Survey

Australians do not require visas to move to New Zealand.

The survey results also found that more people trust New Zealand than Australia to 'act responsibly in the world'.

Only five per cent of respondents were cautious about New Zealand's political intention, while one per cent did not trust the country at all.

Of those who trusted the Kiwis, 64 per cent of Australians trust them 'a lot', while 31 per cent trust them 'somewhat'.

The results show that Aussies trust their next-door neighbours more than they trust their own country.

Only only 36 per cent trust Australia 'a lot' to do the right thing, while 47 per cent only trust their own country 'somewhat'.
description: While many Australians believe they live in the best country in the world, when asked if they had to jump ship most people opted for New Zealand.
authors: Lauren Ferri For Daily Mail Australia
